data.title: Man in Space (1955)
data.meta_description: With a combination of documentary footage and animation, the science and history of rockets, and the effects of space travel on man are illustrated.
data.text:
Interesting pre-moon landing documentary/Wonderful World of Disney TV special utilizing a combination of documentary footage and animation to illustrate the development of the rocket, how it works, and how it will take us to the moon and beyond!

Particularly interesting to see the "Father of Rocket Science", Wernher Von Braun, explain the technology behind rocket technology.

I did Nazi that coming!

FUN FACTS:

-President Eisenhower requested a print of this show to screen at the Pentagon, and a scale model of the space station built for the show was also sent to Washington, where it resides at the National Air and Space Museum.

-One of the few short subjects to be nominated for an Oscar after it premiered on television.…

Directed by Ward Kimball, one of Disney's Nine Old Men, the film employs the studio's signature animation style to bring complex scientific concepts to life at a time when space travel was still in its infancy. This film served as both an educational tool and a source of inspiration for countless viewers. Through cleverly animated sequences, the documentary breaks down the principles of rocketry, space navigation, and zero gravity, making these intricate ideas accessible to viewers of all ages.

What this documentary does best is how it delves into the history of space exploration, tracing humanity's fascination with the stars and the evolution of rocket technology. It pays tribute to the pioneers who contributed to the dream of reaching the…

Son of Hooray for Hollywood

Although it was produced only 6 years before Yuri Gagarin was flung into space, this documentary presents an understandably optimistic view of man's first foray into space, which forms the centrepiece of the production.

What it depicts is something much closer to the Shuttle than what turned out to be the reality. Although in that respect they weren't far off the mark.

But before we get to that we get a potted history of rockets and some speculation on what it would be like to be for man in space, my favourite of which is the idea that an astronaut might be stung by 'mysterious' cosmic rays as they pass through the body.

That history…
